questions.text: Which of the following is the most common congenital anomaly of the kidney?
questions.solution:
The horseshoe kidney is the most common congenital anomaly of the kidney, with an incidence of 1 in 600 live births.

During development, the kidney is initially located in the pelvic region. Later, the kidneys ascend due to the growth of the body in the lumbar and sacral regions. Sometimes, the kidneys are pushed so close to each other during their ascent that their lower poles fuse, forming a horseshoe kidney. 

  • The horseshoe kidney is usually found at the level of the lower lumbar vertebrae.
  • Its ascent is halted by the root of the inferior mesenteric artery.
  • The connecting isthmus of the horseshoe kidney may be present either in front or behind the aorta and the inferior vena cava.

questions.text: ↑ LH secretion just before ovulation is due to_____
questions.solution:
Increased luteinizing hormone (LH) secretion just before ovulation is due to positive feedback by estrogen. 

Phases

Hormone

Type of feedback

Site

FSH and LH secretion

Follicular

Estrogen

Negative

Anterior pituitary

Both suppressed

Midcycle

Estrogen

Positive

Anterior pituitary

Increased LH surge

Luteal

Estrogen

Progesterone

Negative

Negative

Anterior pituitary

Anterior pituitary

Both are decreased

questions.text: Name the procedure depicted in the picture below.
questions.solution:
The picture depicts the nothern blotting technique.


Northern blotting is used for detection of RNA.

Other blotting techniques :

  • Southern blotting is used for detection of DNA.
  • Western blotting is used for detection of protein.

questions.text: In the following osmotic fragility curve, ‘A’ occurs in _________.
questions.solution:
In the given osmotic fragility curve, the green-shaded region is the normal zone of red blood cell hemolysis. Here, curve A is more towards the left, indicating that RBCs have an increased osmotic fragility. When there is an increase in osmotic fragility, hemolysis occurs at a higher concentration of NaCl. Curve A signifies a higher concentration of NaCl in this graph which occurs in hereditary spherocytosis.

In thalassemia and sickle-cell anemia, on the other hand, the red cells become more resistant to osmotic lysis due to which there is a decrease in osmotic fragility. Hence, the curve will shift to the right.

questions.text: The test kit shown in the image below works on the principle of:
questions.solution:
The above image shows a HbsAg card test kit which works on the principle of immunochromatography.

The immunochromatographic membrane is used for antigen detection, while a nitrocellulose membrane is used to absorb the antigen from a specimen. A coloured reaction appears directly on the membrane with the sequential addition of conjugate followed by the substrate. In some cases, the antigen is captured by a bound antibody directed against the antigen. These assays have the advantage of being rapid and also frequently include a built-in internal control.

questions.text: All are correct about the given device below used along with pMDI (pressurized metered-dose inhaler), except:

choices.text: Decreases the deposition of drug on the oropharynx
Increases the delivery of drug to lower airways
Increases the incidence of oropharyngeal candidiasis
Systemic absorption of drugs is unaffected

questions.solution:
The given image is of a spacer device. It decreases the incidence of oropharyngeal candidiasis and other propellant-mediated oropharyngeal adverse effects like dysphonia that occur with the use of a pMDI.

Spacers reduce the velocity and size of particles entering the upper airways. This reduces the amount of drug that impinges on the oropharynx and increases the proportion of drug inhaled into lower airways. The systemic absorption is unchanged by the use of a spacer.

Spacer devices are useful in delivering inhaled drugs to children who are not able to use a pMDI alone but can also be used by adults for better drug delivery.

questions.text: The classic signs of asphyxia are no longer considered to be relevant to the diagnosis of asphyxia, due to their absence in many cases of asphyxial death. But, in which  of the following types of asphyxia can one see the most extreme demonstration of these 'classic signs of asphyxia'?
questions.solution:
The most extreme demonstration of the 'classic signs of asphyxia' is seen in a case of traumatic asphyxia.

Classic signs of asphyxia:

  • For many years the autopsy diagnosis of an asphyxial death was made by reference to a set of findings that have come to be known as the ‘classic signs of asphyxia’.

  • Unfortunately, it is now quite clear that most of these signs are so non-specific that little reliance can be placed on them in the absence of other confirmatory evidence. They are scathingly referred to by Lester Adelson as the ‘obsolete diagnostic quintet’.

  • The four signs are:
    1. Petechial haemorrhages
    2. Congestion and edema
    3. Cyanosis
    4. Engorgement of the right heart and abnormal fluidity of the blood.

Regarding traumatic asphyxia:

  • It means mechanical fixation of the chest. ‘Traumatic asphyxia’ acts by restricting respiratory movements and thus prevents inspiration. 

  • It provides the most extreme demonstration of the ‘classic signs’ of asphyxia.

questions.text: A 20 yr old male was brought to casualty in unconscious state after a head injury. On examination, CSF rhinorrhea and Battle sign are noted. Which of the following most likely occured to this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with a battle sign, indicates a skull base fracture associated with bruising over mastoid process. Battle sign and CSF rhinorrhea are features of a middle cranial fossa fracture.

Middle cranial fossa fracture is associated with:

  • CSF otorrhea or rhinorrhea
  • Hemotympanum
  • Ossicular disruption
  • Battle sign: Bruising behind the ear
  • 7th and 8th cranial nerve palsies

CSF rhinorrhea or otorrhea: Double target sign, a double-ring pattern described with CSF-containing bloody fluid from the ear or nose, when dripped onto paper or linen.

Double target sign is seen patients with CSF rhinorrhea. The nasal discharge in a patient with CSF rhinorrhea after head trauma is mixed with blood. When this discharge is collected on a filter paper, it shows a double target sign with a central red spot and a peripheral lighter halo as seen in the image below. 

The image below shows the 'battle' sign.

Anterior cranial fossa fracture is associated with:

  • Subconjunctival hematoma
  • CSF rhinorrhea
  • Carotico-cavernous fistula
  • Periorbital hematoma or “Raccoon eyes”

Periorbital ecchymosis (raccoon eyes): Pooling of blood surrounding the eyes, associated with fractures of the anterior cranial fossa (given below). 

Other options:

Option A: Duret hemorrhages are delayed, secondary brainstem hemorrhages. They occur in craniocerebral trauma victims with rapidly evolving descending transtentorial herniation. They are typically located in the ventral and paramedian aspects of the upper brainstem.

Option B: Kernohan phenomenon is a radiological finding resulting from extensive midline shift due to mass effect, resulting in indentation in the contralateral cerebral crus by the tentorium cerebelli. 

Option D: An epidural hematoma forms between the skull and the dura mater, which also occurs after a head injury, but presents with a lucid interval. 

Related Pearl: Signs of base of skull fracture

Signs of Base of Skull Fracture

  • Bilateral periorbital haematoma (raccoon eyes)
  • Battle’s sign (bruising over mastoid)
  • CSF rhinorrhoea or otorrhoea
  • Haemotympanum or bleeding from ear

questions.text: The following test was done on a patient with squint and the finding noted is shown. What is the defect seen in the left eye?
questions.solution:
The test shown is the cover - uncover test. There is abduction of the eye with suspected deviation (left eye) on covering the fixing eye (right eye) which suggests left esotropia.

This test consists of two parts:

  • Cover test
  • Uncover test

Cover Test: This is used to detect heterotropia (manifest squint). Light is first shone and corneal reflections are observed. This is done to assess fixation in the deviating eye. The procedure for testing using an accommodative target and for distance is as follows.

  • The patient is asked to fixate on a target straight ahead.
  • The eye in which deviation is not suspected is covered first. For example, if a right eye deviation is suspected, the left eye is covered.
  • Any movement of the right eye to take up fixation is noted.
  • The following are the possible results:
Movement of the eye Suspected defect
No movements Orthotropia/Heterotropia of the covered eye
Adduction Exotropia
Abduction Esotropia
Downward movement Hypertropia
Upward movement Hypotropia

The test is then repeated for the opposite eye.

Uncover test: This is used to detect heterophoria (latent squint). The test is performed for both near and distant as follows.

  • The patient fixates a distant target straight ahead.
  • The examiner covers an eye for 2-3 seconds and the cover is then removed.
  • If the covered eye had deviated, a re-fixation movement is observed on being uncovered.
  • The following are the possible results based on the re-fixation movements of the eye.
Movement of the eye Suspected defect
No movements Orthophoria
Adduction (Nasal recovery) Exophoria
Abduction Esophoria
Downward/Upward movement Vertical phoria
  • The speed and smoothness of the recovery is noted as well as evidence of the strength of motor fusion.
  • The test is then repeated for the opposite eye.

questions.text: A medical student  is preparing to do a prospective cohort study for the association of hypertension  with CHD from the general medicine wards. Which of the following must she do?

choices.text: Exclude  all patients diagnosed with hypertension recently
Exclude all the patients on antihypertensive medications
Exclude all the  patients with diagnosis of CHD
Exclude all the patients diagnosed with hypertension more than 3 years back

questions.solution:
Cohort studies progress from cause to effect. Thus, the patients with CHD must be excluded. The study begins before the disease under study has occurred.

ANALYTICAL EPIDEMIOLOGY

 Analytical studies differ from descriptive studies in that the the subject of interest is the individual within the population whereas in descriptive studies the entire population is studied. 

Analytical studies includes :
      (i) Case control study
      (ii) Cohort study.

By performing an analytical study one can find :
(i) if a statistical association exists between a disease and a suspected factor or not ; and
(ii) if there is one , the strength of the Association.

 Differences between case control and cohort studies:

Case control study Cohort study
1. Proceeds from "effect to cause". Proceeds from "cause to effect"
2. Starts with the disease Starts with people exposed to risk factor or suspected cause.
3. Tests whether the suspected cause occurs more frequently in those with the disease than among those without the disease. Tests whether disease occurs more frequently in those exposed, than in those not similarly exposed.
4. Usually the first approach to the testing or a hypothesis, but also useful for exploratory studies. Reserved for testing of precisely formulated hypothesis.
5. Involves fewer number or subjects Involves larger number of subjects.
6. Yields relatively quick results. Long follow-up period often needed. involving delayed results.
7. Suitable for the study of rare diseases. Inappropriate when the disease or exposure under investigation is rare.
8. Generally yields only estimate of RR (odds ratio). Yields incidence rates, RR as well as AR.
9. Cannot yield information about diseases other than that selected for study. Can yield information about more than one disease outcome.
10. Relatively inexpensive Expensive.

Related Pearl: Cohort Study

  • A cohort study progresses from cause to effect, as exposure has occured but not disease.
  • It is also known as forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study.
  • Design of a Cohort Study
    • Types
      • Prospective cohort studies (concurrent cohort studies)
      • Retrospective cohort studies (historical cohort study)
      • Combination cohort studies
    • Steps
      • Selection of study subjects
      • Obtaining data on exposure
      • Selection of comparison groups
      • Follow-up
      • Analysis in terms of incidence rates and estimation of risk
    • Advantages and disadvantages

Advantages

Disadvantages

Incidence can be calculated.

Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied at same time.

Provides direct estimate of relative risk

Calculation of dose-response ratio

Minimization of certain biases

Cannot be used for uncommon diseases

Uses a large population

Takes a long time to complete

Many common administrative problems

Attrition is high.

Selection of subjects is difficult.

Dynamism of diagnostics is difficult to incorporate.

Tend to be expensive.

Tends to alter behaviour of subjects: Hawthorne effect.

Ethical problems

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

  • In a case control study, progression is from effect to cause as outcome or disease has already occurred.
  • It is also called retrospective study.
  • Design of Case Control Study

 

    • Steps of Case Control Study
      • Selection of cases and controls
      • Matching
      • Measurement of exposure
      • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
    • Advantages and Disadvantages

Advantages

Disadvantages

Easy to carry out

Rapid and inexpensive

Requires few subjects

Used to investigate rare diseases

No risk to subjects

Different etiological factors can be studied.

Risk factors can be identified.

No attrition problems

Minimal ethical problems

Relies on memory or past records which can give rise to bias

Selection of appropriate control groups may be difficult.

Incidence cannot be measured.

Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors

Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis

Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the global hunger index (GHI)?

choices.text: Percentage of  undernourished children under  5 years

questions.solution:
The infant mortality rate is not a component of the global hunger index.

The Global Hunger Index (GHI) has three dimensions. These dimensions are measured by indicators. 

Dimensions Indicators
Inadequate food supply Proportion of the population undernourished
Child mortality Under 5 mortality rate
Child undernutrition Wasting in children under 5 years
Stunting in children under 5 years

GHI score = (1/3 X standardized PUN) + (1/6 X standardised CWA) + (1/6 X standardised CST) + (1/3 X Standardised CM)

Where,

  • PUN is the proportion of the population that is undernourished
  • CWA is the prevalence of wasting in children under 5 years of age
  • CST is the prevalence of stunting in children under 5 years of age
  • CM is the proportion of children dying under the age of 5 years of age.

The result lies on a scale from 0 to 100, with 0 meaning no hunger and 100 being the worst score. The GHI is given by the International Food Policy Research Institute. In 2021, India's GHI was 27.5. It ranks 101 among 116 countries. In the 2022,India's GHI stands at 29.1, and India ranks 107th out of the 121 countries.

questions.text: Which of the following group of individuals would not be targeted under the program represented by the logo shown below?

choices.text: Men who have sex with men

questions.solution:
The red ribbon shown is a part of the logo of the National AIDS Control Organization (NACO) program. Industrial workers are not included in the target population under NACO.

Target interventions for the control of AIDS transmission are done for:

  • High-risk groups like sex workers
  • Men who have sex with men
  • Transgender
  • Injecting drug users
  • Bridge populations like migrants and long-distance truckers

The services offered through targeted interventions include detection and treatment for sexually transmitted diseases and condom distribution.

The logo of NACO:

questions.text: During your casualty rotation, you accidentally injure yourself while suturing a patient. You had taken the full schedule of hepatitis B vaccination during your first year of medical school. Which of the following markers will you get measured to determine the need for HBIG administration?
questions.solution:
The need for administration of hepatitis B hyperimmune globulin (HBIG) in a previously vaccinated individual can be determined based on anti-HBsAg levels. It is the marker for determining the efficacy of hepatitis B vaccination.

The complete hepatitis B vaccine schedule consists of three intramuscular doses at 0, 1, and 6 months.

Post Exposure Prophylaxis:

The prophylaxis can be done using the hepatitis B vaccine or hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG).

Vaccination status of the exposed person Recommended prophylaxis
Unvaccinated HBIG (0.06 mL/kg) and initiate hepatitis B vaccine series
Known responder to previous vaccination (anti-HBs titer>10 mIU/mL) No action required
Non-responder to previous vaccination (anti-HBs titer <10 mIU/mL) HBIG: 2 doses (1 month apart) OR HBIG: 1 dose + initiate hepatitis B revaccination.

Related Pearl: Interpretation of common serologic patterns in hepatitis B infection

 

 Clinical Phases HBsAg Anti-HBs HBeAg Anti-HBe Anti-HBc HBV DNA
Acute HBV - Early-phase, high infectivity

+

 - + - IgM +++

Acute HBV -Window phase

-

 - - - IgM +

Acute HBV - recovery phase

-

 + - + IgG +/-
Chronic HBV, high infectivity + - + - IgG +++

Chronic HBV, low infectivity

 + - - + IgG +

HBV infection in the recent past

 - + - - IgG -

HBV infection in the remote past

 - - - +/- IgG -

Post-vaccination

 - + - - - -

questions.text: A 22-year old man presents with diarrhea and intolerance to dairy products. On investigation, he was found to have a lactase deficiency. Which of the following agents is least likely to cause symptoms of lactose intolerance?
questions.solution:
Yoghurt is least likely to cause symptoms of lactose intolerance. It contains bacteria that produce lactase and is generally well tolerated.

Lactase is a brush border enzyme that hydrolyzes lactose into glucose and galactose. In lactase deficiency, patients have great variability in clinical symptoms, depending on both the severity of lactase deficiency and the amount of lactose ingested.

The goal of treatment in patients with isolated lactase deficiency is achieving patient comfort through the elimination of dietary lactose.

Foods that are high in lactose include milk (12 g/cup), ice cream (9 g/cup) and cottage cheese (8 g/cup). Aged cheese has lower lactose content. Most people can tolerate up to 12g of lactose a day without significant symptoms.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with recurrent paranasal sinus pain and occasional hemoptysis. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated ESR and red cell casts in the urine. Serology is positive for cANCA. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's granulomatosis). The patient shows the involvement of the upper respiratory tract (sinusitis), lower respiratory tract (occasional hemoptysis), renal system (red cell casts), and the presence of cANCA antibodies.

It is a granulomatous, necrotizing vasculitis of the small vessels which mainly affects

  • Upper respiratory tract- presenting with sinusitis, otitis media, and nasal septal perforation
  • Lower respiratory tract- presenting with hemoptysis
  • Renals (glomerulonephritis)- presenting with proteinuria, hematuria, and hypertension.

Apart from these organs, the disease can also affect the eye and skin. Skin lesions present as palpable purpura or subcutaneous nodules. Laboratory investigations show anemia, leucocytosis, elevated ESR, and cANCA positivity.

questions.text: A 35-year-old sustained a crush injury and he says his urine is brownish in colour. On investigation, his urine/plasma creatinine levels were <20. What could be the possible cause?
questions.solution:
A history of crush injury along with brownish urine and urine/plasma creatinine ratio of <20 is observed in renal AKI, which can be caused by rhabdomyolysis in this case.

Rhabdomyolysis is a serious life-threatening condition that involves a rapid breakdown of damaged skeletal muscle cells due to direct or indirect injury. Muscle breakdown causes the release of myoglobin, which contains heme into the bloodstream, causing heme pigment nephropathy. The heme pigment can cause direct PCT injury and vasoconstriction leading to fractional excretion of sodium(FENa)less than 1. Pigmented granular cast precipitates in the tubule causing oliguria and renal failure.

Causative factors include:

  • Traumatic crush injuries
  • Muscle ischemia during vascular or orthopaedic surgery
  • Compression during coma or immobilization
  • Prolonged seizure activity
  • Excessive or strenuous exercise
  • Heatstroke or malignant hyperthermia
  • Infections
  • Metabolic disorders such as hypophosphatemia or severe hypothyroidism
  • Myopathies (drug-induced, metabolic, or inflammatory)

Skeletal muscle damage causes excessive release of myoglobin, which acts as an endogenous toxin and can cause acute renal failure.

Laboratory features include elevated myoglobin, creatine kinase. Hematuria on dipstick examination without red cells indicates the presence of myoglobin.

The treatment includes administration of large amounts of fluid (5-6 liters), alkalization of urine, and hemodialysis. 

The rest of the options include causes of prerenal AKI, wherein the urine/plasma creatinine is >40.

  Pre renal  Renal Post renal
Urine osmolality >500 mOsm/kg <350mOsm/kg < 400 mOsm/kg
Urine Na <20 meq/l >40meq/l Variable
FeNa <1 >2 Variable
Urine creatinine/plasma creatinine >40:1 <20:1 <20:1
BUN: Creatinine  >20:1 <20:1 >20:1
Urine microscopy  Hyaline Muddy brown cast Normal or RBC/WBC

Causes of AKI are given below:

questions.text:
The complications associated with refeeding syndrome are:
  1. Hyperkalemia
  2. Hypomagnesemia
  3. Hypercalcemia
  4. Hypophosphatemia
questions.solution:
Hypomagnesemia and hypophosphatemia, both occur in refeeding syndrome.

1 and 3 are false as, hypokalemia and hypocalcemia (NOT hyper), are complications of refeeding syndrome.

Refeeding syndrome is a fatal condition that can occur with rapid and excessive feeding of patients with severe underlying malnutrition which may be due to:

  • Starvation
  • Alcoholism
  • Delayed nutritional support
  • Anorexia nervosa
  • Massive weight loss in obese patients

It can occur with either enteral or parenteral nutrition, but is more common with the latter.

With excessive refeeding, there is a shift in metabolism from fat to carbohydrate substrate which stimulates excessive insulin release. As a result, there is an increase in the cellular uptake of electrolytes, particularly phosphate, magnesium, potassium, and calcium.

Hence the metabolic abnormalities include:

  • Hypophosphatemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hypokalemia
  • Hypocalcemia

These electrolyte disorders can result in myocardial infarction, arrhythmias, respiratory dysfunction, liver dysfunction, seizures, confusion, coma, tetany, and death.

Prevention and treatment:

  • Correct underlying electrolyte and volume deficits.
  • Additionally, thiamine should be administered before the initiation of feeding. Caloric replenition should be instituted slowly and should gradually increase over the first week.
  • Vital signs, fluid balance, and electrolytes should be closely monitored and any deficits corrected as they evolve.

questions.text: A neonate presented with mild intermittent upper abdominal pain.On examination, the infant has a scaphoid abdomen and breath sounds are decreased on both sides. X-ray is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture of respiratory distress, intermittent abdominal pain, scaphoid abdomen, absent breath sounds in both sides of the chest, and an X-ray image showing bowel loops in the thoracic cavity is diagnostic of congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH), the most common variant being Bochdalek hernia.

If the defect is posterolateral it is called Bochdalek hernia and if it's anteromedial it is called Morgagni hernia. 

Clinical features :

  • Respiratory distress is a cardinal sign in infants with a congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH).
  • Early respiratory distress, within 6 hr after birth, is thought to be a poor prognostic sign.
  • Children with CDH may also have a scaphoid abdomen and increased chest wall diameter.
  • Bowel sounds may also be heard in the chest, with a bilateral decrease in breath sounds.
  • The point of maximal cardiac impulse may be displaced away from the side of a hernia if a mediastinal shift has occurred.
  • Retroperitoneal fat, left kidney, spleen or only the omentum commonly herniates through the defect. If the defect is large, most abdominal contents including the stomach may herniate.

Diagnosis:

  • Chest radiography and passage of a nasal gastric tube confirm the diagnosis.
  • CDH can be diagnosed on prenatal ultrasonography (between 16 and 24 weeks of gestation)
  • High-speed fetal magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) can further define the lesion.

Differential diagnosis:

  • Diaphragmatic eventration
  • Cystic adenomatoid malformation
  • Bronchogenic cyst
  • Cystic teratoma

Treatment:

Variable period of time (24-72 hours) to allow for stabilization before surgical repair. Immediate respiratory support should be provided, including rapid endotracheal intubation and sedation. 

Bag and Mask Ventilation is contraindicated in newborns with congenital diaphragmatic hernia because it causes distension of the stomach which in turn may limit the expansion of the already hypoplastic lung.

During surgery, the viscera are reduced into the abdominal cavity, and the posterolateral defect in the diaphragm is closed using interrupted, nonabsorbable sutures.

In most cases (80%-90%), a hernia sac is not present. If identified, it is excised at the time of repair.

Conventional mechanical ventilation, high-frequency oscillatory ventilation (HFOV), and extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) are the 3 main strategies to support respiratory failure in the newborn with CDH.

Good relative indicators of stability are as follows:

  • Requirement for conventional ventilation only
  • Low peak inspiratory pressure
  • Fi-O2 <50

If the defect is too large, a porous polytetrafluoroethylene (Gore-Tex) patch is used.

Other options:

Gastric volvulus: This is an uncommon condition and presents with the characteristic Borchardt triad which includes:

  • Sudden-onset severe upper abdominal pain
  • Recurrent retching with the production of little vomitus
  • Inability to pass a nasogastric (NG) tube

It can be organoaxial or mesentroaxial. Chest X-ray may show intrathoracic upside-down stomach and retrosternal or mediastinal air-fluid level.

Image showing intrathoracic gastric volvulus with mediastinal gastric bubble-

Eventration of the diaphragm: It refers to the abnormal contour of the dome of the diaphragm without any disruption to the diaphragmatic continuity. It usually involves a segment of the hemidiaphragm. It can cause respiratory distress in newborns and is usually asymptomatic in adults.

Radiographic findings: The affected portion of the hemidiaphragm is elevated and is seen as a smooth hump, while the normal contour is seen in the remaining part. 'Double diaphragmatic contour' may be seen in frontal view and is confirmed with a lateral X-ray.

Image showing eventration of the right dome of the diaphragm-

questions.text: Identify the imaging modality.
questions.solution:
The image depicts a retrograde pyelogram.

Retrograde Pyelogram is particularly valuable when IVP/CT is contraindicated and excels at providing detailed imaging of the collecting system, especially for evaluating ureteral strictures and filling defects, making it especially useful in surgical planning. 

Other Options:

Option B: In Retrograde urethrogram, the urethra is visualized with the instillation of contrast into the anterior urethra (penile urethra and bulbar urethra). It helps diagnose anterior urethral abnormalities. The following image shows an image of retrograde urethrogram contrast leakage at the membranous urethra.

Option C: Intravenous Pyelography (IVP) provides comprehensive visualization of the entire urinary collecting system, useful for detecting stones, tumors, and anatomical abnormalities, though it's becoming less common with the advent of CT urography and has limitations in patients with renal insufficiency or contrast allergies. 

Option D: Antegrade Pyelography, performed through a nephrostomy tube, is particularly useful when retrograde access isn't possible and helps evaluate obstruction below the kidney, often being employed in patients with existing nephrostomy tubes. The image shows an antegrade pyelogram of grade III hydronephrosis with obstruction at the ureterovesical junction.

questions.text: A young male patient presents with pain during defecation along with the presence of blood-streaked stools. He has had a history of constipation for 5 months. On examination, a sentinel tag is present at the anal orifice. Due to extreme pain, a digital rectal examination is avoided. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This case scenario with a history of chronic constipation, and the presence of sentinel tags on examination, suggests a diagnosis of anal fissure.

An anal fissure is a longitudinal split in the anoderm of the distal anal canal. A chronic anal fissure frequently is associated with :

  • Sentinel tag externally
  • Hypertrophied anal papillae internally
  • Anal ulcer overlying the internal sphincter

Anal fissures are usually seen in the young but they can occur at any age with equal sex predilection. Severe pain associated with defecation resolves spontaneously and reappears during the next evacuation. It may even be associated with the passage of fresh blood. 

Most of the fissures are located in the posterior midline followed by the anterior midline. Fissures located anywhere around the anal circumference can be possible due to other diseases like HIV, tuberculosis, syphilis, Crohn's disease, or carcinoma.

Treatment of anal fissure:

  • The focus is to normalize bowel habits. Bowel softeners, dietary fibres, and adequate water should be recommended.
  • Medical therapy involves the topical application of glyceryl trinitrate. It releases nitric oxide and relaxes the internal anal sphincter. This reduces spasms, and pain and improves vasculature to promote healing.
  • Surgical therapy is recommended for chronic fissures that have failed medical therapy. Lateral internal sphincterotomy is the procedure of choice where a portion of the internal sphincter is divided away from the fissure. 

Other options:

Option A: Anal fistula is usually associated with pain and intermittent purulent discharge. On examination, an external opening in the perineum can be found which opens internally in the anal canal.

Option C: Hemorrhoids are enlargements of anal cushions which occur commonly due to raised intra-abdominal pressure(e.g. constipation and pregnancy). They present with bright-red painless bleeding, pruritus, mucus discharge, and prolapsed hemorrhoids. Pain is not a common feature and is present if haemorrhoids are thrombosed.

Option D: Rectal prolapse presents as a mass protruding out of the anal canal. It is seen more commonly in females and may be associated with faecal incontinence.

questions.text: A male had a vasectomy 1 month ago and the couple asks the doctor if they have to take any precautions while having sex. What advice should be given?

choices.text: Oral contraceptive pills for 1 month for the woman
Hormonal treatment given for 2 more months for the man

questions.solution:
The best advice is to use condoms for 3 months as the sperms are stored in the reproductive tract for upto 3 months. 

Vasectomy

  • Vasectomy consists of dividing the vas deferens and disrupting the passage of sperms.
  • It is done through a small incision in the scrotum, under local anesthesia. The sterility is not immediate. The sperms are stored in the reproductive tract for up to 3 months. The couple must therefore abstain from intercourse during this period or use other methods of contraception.
  • Approximately, 20 ejaculates clear the semen of all sperms. Two semen analysis reports must confirm the absence of sperms before the man can be declared sterile.
  • No-scalpel technique has been now adopted. One single incision is made with a special forceps, and skin stitch is not required. Clips and plugs can be applied over the vas instead of cutting. Vasectomy is cheaper than tubectomy

questions.text: An 11-year-old girl is evaluated using Tanner's staging. The breast is elevated like a small mound, with the appearance of pigmented hair sparsely over the labia, either long or slightly curved. This is given as ______ stage.
questions.solution:
This girl has stage 2 according to Tanner's staging

  • Initial development of breast and pubic hairs is given by Tanners 1 and 2. 
  • Tanners 4 & 5 refer to advance stages of breast and pubic hair development.

Tanners stages describe pubertal changes 

Tanners  Breast changes  Pubic hair changes 
Stage 1

Denotes the prepubertal breast. At this infantile stage, only the papilla is elevated.

 (B1)		 No pubic hair (P1)
Stage 2

Denotes thelarche. The breast buds are palpable, areola enlarges and the breast is elevated like a small mound (B2)

 The appearance of pigmented hair sparsely over the labia, either long or slightly curved (P2)
Stage 3

There is further enlargement of the breast and its areola without separation of its contours (B3)

 Darker coarser and curly hair (P3)
Stage 4

Preferential growth of the areola and nipple leads to formation of a secondary mound over the mound of the breast (B4)

 Preadult stage cover short inverted triangular distribution (P4)
Stage 5

Formation of the mature adult breast (B5)

  Adult inverted triangular distributuion (P5)

questions.text: A 26-year-old female patient with a history of two-second trimester abortions presents to the OG clinic with 6 weeks of amenorrhea and a positive UPT. She was diagnosed to have cervical incompetence after the previous abortion.  What is the best timing to do prophylactic cerclage in this patient______
questions.solution:
Prophylactic cervical cerclage is done between 12 to 14 weeks gestation.

The timing of surgery depends on clinical circumstances. 

  • Elective cerclage(based on previous obstetric outcomes) is usually done between 12 and 14 weeks gestation.
  • If the diagnosis is made in high-risk women using transvaginal sonography to document cervical shortening < 25 mm, then therapeutic cerclage is done at that time.
  • For the remainder who undergo emergency rescue cerclage, it can be done until 24 weeks of gestation.

questions.text: A newborn child born to a mother with sickle cell disease is to be screened for sickle cell anaemia. Which of the following tests can be used?
questions.solution:
High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) is used for newborn screening of sickle cell anaemia and thalassemia.

Other options:

  • Haemoglobin electrophoresis is the confirmatory test for sickle cell anaemia and other hemoglobinopathies. e.g., thalassemia
  • Heel-prick Guthrie test is the neonatal screening test for phenylketonuria.
  • Tandem mass spectrometry is being used for neonatal screening of inherited metabolic disorders.

In India, a universal newborn screening program has been initiated only in some states which have high prevalence with plans to extend it to other areas.

questions.text: The fracture seen in the Xray given below is?
questions.solution:
The X-ray reveals an oblique fracture in the lower third of radius with dislocation of the distal radio-ulnar joint, which is suggestive of Galeazzi's fracture. 

In Galeazzi's fracture, the radial bone is fractured at the junction of middle and distal third with subluxation or dislocation of distal radio-ulnar joint. 

Complications include :

  • Malunion
  • Nonunion
  • Entrapment of extensor carpi ulnaris tendon in distal radio-ulnar joint

Option B: Monteggia fracture: It is the fracture of shaft of ulna with dislocation of proximal radio-ulnar joint

Option C: Smith's fracture: It is also known as "Reverse Colle's fracture". It is the fracture of the distal radius with palmar angulation of the distal bone fragment.

Option D: Colle's fracture: It is the fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar displacement.

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius.

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of the ulnar bone.

questions.text: Five days after giving birth to a healthy baby, 29-year-old Rita is experiencing moodiness, tearfulness, and lack of energy. You counsel her and provide her with a booklet educating her on postpartum blues. How long should her symptoms persist before she should be evaluated for postpartum depression?
questions.solution:
The patient should be evaluated for postpartum depression if her symptoms last longer than 2 weeks.

Postpartum blues is common in mothers in the puerperal period. It is characterized by transient mood disturbances like a labile mood, sadness, and subjective confusion. It is thought to be due to changes in hormone levels, the stress of childbirth, and anxiety about the responsibilities of motherhood. Treatment is nothing more than education and support, however, symptoms lasting longer than 2 weeks should be evaluated for postpartum depression.

Postpartum depression is characterized by a depressed mood, excessive anxiety, insomnia, anhedonia, and a change in weight, usually within the first 12 weeks postpartum. There may be associated thoughts of suicide or of harming the baby, which is not present in postpartum blues.

Postpartum psychosis (or puerperal psychosis), is a psychotic disorder that may occur in women who have recently delivered a baby. It is characterized by depression, delusions, and thoughts of harming either herself or her infant.  Such ideation of suicide or infanticide should be carefully monitored. It is listed as a subtype of bipolar disorder in DSM-5.

The onset of psychotic symptoms is usually preceded by insomnia, restlessness, agitation, lability of mood, and mild cognitive deficits. Later, suspiciousness, confusion, incoherence, irrational statements, and obsessive thoughts about the baby's health and welfare develop. The mean time of onset is usually within the first 2-3 weeks following delivery, although it can occur in the first few days. Subsequent pregnancies are associ­ated with an increased risk of a second episode.

Postpartum psychosis is a psychiatric emergency. The treatment of choice involves antipsychotics and lithium, with an antidepressant. 
Suicidal patients require admission to a psy­chiatric unit. The mother is allowed supervised contact with her baby if she desires. Psychother­apy is indicated after the period of acute psychosis.

questions.text: The type of laryngoscope blade shown in the given image is:
questions.solution:
The given image shows Miller laryngoscopic blade.

Miller is a straight blade laryngoscope, used in:

  • Neonates, infants and young children
  • Adults with short thyromental distance and long floppy epiglottis.

Laryngoscopic blades can be

  • Straight blade, Miller
  • Curved blade, Macintosh

Advantage of curved blade:

  • Greater room available for the passage for an endotracheal tube
  • Less damage to the teeth

questions.text: A baby is brought to the hospital with the following lesions on the body. The lesion started 2 days ago and has increased in number. Similar lesions are also present on the lower limbs. Examination of the oral cavity also has similar lesions. Which of the following infection most commonly proceeds with this skin condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows target lesions that are seen in erythema multiforme. Infection with Herpes simplex commonly proceeds with this skin condition.

Erythema Multiforme is a self‐limiting cytotoxic dermatitis resulting from cell‐mediated hypersensitivity most commonly to infection or drugs.

The common triggers are

  • Herpes simplex infection
  • Mycoplasma infection
  • Bacterial infections
  • Fungal infections
  • Vaccinations
  • Malignancy: carcinoma, lymphoma, leukemia
  • Drug reactions: sulfonamides, cotrimoxazole, penicillins
  • Miscellaneous: Lupus erythematosus (Rowell Syndrome), Sarcoidosis, Polyarteritis Nodosa

It presents clinically with macular, popular, or urticarial lesions, along with the classic acral iris or target lesions. The lesions are distributed on the distal extremities, palms or trunk, and oral and genital mucous membranes.

Target lesions are less than 3 cm in diameter, rounded, and have three zones:

  • The central area of dusky erythema or purpura
  • Middle paler zone of edema
  • The outer ring of erythema with a well‐defined edge

Atypical lesions will have only 2 zones. They fade in 1-2 weeks leaving dusky discoloration.

 

Related Pearl: Erythema multiforme vs. Stevens-Johnson syndrome/Toxic epidermal necrolysis

Earlier, erythema multiforme (EM), Stevens–Johnson syndrome (SJS), toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN or Lyell syndrome) were considered to form a spectrum from mild to fulminatingly severe cases. Now, this has been revised to separate Erythema multiforme as part of a different spectrum.

Erythema Multiforme is regarded as a self‐limiting cytotoxic dermatitis resulting from cell‐mediated hypersensitivity most commonly to infection or drugs.


Stevens–Johnson syndrome (SJS) and toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) are severe mucocutaneous reactions, usually to drugs, characterized by blistering and epithelial sloughing. The two terms describe phenotypes within a severity spectrum, in which SJS is the less extensive form and TEN is the more extensive.

  Erythema multiforme major Stevens-Johnsons Syndrome Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis
% Body Surface-area <10% <10% >30%
Causes Herpes simplex> Mycoplasma infection Drug induced e.g. cephalosporins, sulfa drugs, allopurinol Drug induced e.g. cephalosporins, sulfa drugs, allopurinol
Associated Symptoms Less fever and other constitutional symptoms Fever, malaise and headache Fever, malaise and headache
Mucosal Lesions Milder mucosal lesions Severe mucosal involvement Severe mucosal involvement
Lesions Erythematous papules, Target lesions, raised atypical target lesions, occasional bullous lesions

Vesicles on erythematous base, erosions, purpuric macules, Flat atypical target lesions

Nikolsky Sign Positive

Diffuse, generalized epidermal detachment

TEN with spots - with widespread purpuric macules and flat atypical target lesions

TEN without spots- loss of large epidermal sheets without purpuric macules or target lesions

 Nikolsky Sign Positive
Distribution Acral – distal extremities Variable distribution Extensive distribution
Histo-pathology Interface dermatitis – Basal cell vacuolization, apoptotic bodies and inflammatory cells at Dermo-epidermal junction Dermo-epidermal separation, Intense inflammatory cell infiltrates in dermis, some areas of epidermal detachment  Epidermal necrosis, Dermo-epidermal separation, minimal dermal inflammatory cell infiltrate, large areas of epidermal detachment.
Recurrence Common, related to Herpes infections Uncommon, drug-related Uncommon, drug-related
Mortality Rare – recovery in 1 to 4 weeks Elevated mortality Highest mortality

 

Note: Overlap SJS-TEN: There is detachment of 10–30% body surface area, plus widespread purpuric macules or flat atypical targets.

Related Pearl: Glossary of important skin lesions

Glossary of Important Skin Lesions

Lesion

Description

Alopecia

Absence of hair from a normally hairy area

Aphtha

A small ulcer of the mucosa

Atrophy

Loss of tissue from one or more of the epidermis, dermis or subcutaneous tissues

Burrow

A small tunnel in the skin that houses a parasite, such as the scabies acarus

Callus

A localized hyperplasia of the stratum corneum

Cellulitis

An inflammation of cellular tissue, particularly purulent inflammation of the deep dermis and subcutaneous tissue

Comedo

A plug of keratin and sebum in a dilated pilosebaceous orifice

Crusts (scabs)

Crusts consist of dried serum and other exudates

Cyst

Any closed cavity or sac (normal or abnormal) with an epithelial, endothelial or membranous lining and containing fluid or semi‐solid material

Ecchymosis

A macular area of hemorrhage more than 1 cm (bruise) in diameter

Erosion

A loss of epidermis, which heals without scarring. It commonly follows a blister.

Erythema

Redness of the skin produced by vascular congestion or increased perfusion

Excoriation

Loss of skin substance, specifically produced by scratching

Exfoliation

The splitting off of the epidermal keratin in scales or sheets

Fibrosis

The formation of excessive fibrous tissue

Fissure

Any linear gap or slit in the skin surface

Fistula

An abnormal passage from a deep structure, such as a hollow viscus, to the skin surface or between two structures

Gangrene

Death of tissue, usually due to loss of blood supply

Guttate lesions

Small round or oval lesions distributed as a ‘shower’ of droplets. Usually applied to a form of psoriasis

Haematoma

A localized tumour‐like collection of blood

Keratoderma

A horny thickening of the skin

Lichenification

Thickening of the epidermis (and to some extent also of the dermis) in response to prolonged rubbing

Macule

A flat circumscribed, non‐palpable lesion that differs in colour from the surrounding skin. It can be of any colour or shape. A macule is <1 cm in diameter, larger lesions are a patch.

Maculopapular

Rash consisting of both macules and papules

Milium

A tiny white cyst containing lamellated keratin

Nodule*

A solid palpable lesion in the dermis or subcutis, which can be observed as an elevation or can be palpated. It is >0.5 cm in diameter.

Papule

An elevated solid lesion that is < 1cm in diameter.

Petechia

A punctate haemorrhagic spot, approximately 1–2 mm in diameter.

Plaque

An elevated circumscribed lesion > 1 cm diameter; its surface is usually flat. Plaques may form from coalesced papules.

Poikiloderma

The association of cutaneous pigmentation, and telangiectasia.

Pustule

A circumscribed lesion that contains purulent material. 

Pyoderma

Any purulent skin disease

Scale

Scale is a flat plate or flake-like lesion desquamated of stratum corneum.

Scar

Replacement by fibrous tissue of another tissue that has been destroyed by injury or disease

An atrophic scar is thin and wrinkled.

A hypertrophic scar is elevated, with excessive growth of fibrous tissue.

Sclerosis

Diffuse or circumscribed induration of the subcutaneous tissues. It may also involve the dermis, when the overlying epidermis may be atrophic. It is characteristically seen in scleroderma.

Sinus

A cavity or track with a blind ending

Target lesions

These are <3 cm in diameter and have three or more zones, usually a central area of dusky erythema or purpura, a middle paler zone of oedema, and an outer ring of erythema with a well‐defined edge.

Tumour

Literally a swelling; the term is used to imply enlargement of the tissues by normal or pathological material, or cells that form a mass. 

Ulcer (of skin)

A loss of dermis and epidermis, often with loss of the underlying tissues
Vesicles and Bullae

 A vesicle is a circumscribed elevation <0.5cm in diameter that contains fluid

Bullae are >0.5 cm in diameter 
Wheal  A transient elevation of the skin due to dermal and hypodermal, often pale centrally with an erythematous rim; it is the characteristic lesion of urticaria.

 *While Rook's textbook of Dermatology,9th edition mention nodule as >0.5cm. Some authors define nodules as >1cm.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis based on the image shown below?
questions.solution:
The X-ray gives the diagnosis of bladder stones. The tip of a catheter can also be seen in the Xray.

Primary bladder stone:

  • Develops in sterile urine in the absence of any known functional, anatomic, or infectious factors and does not necessarily imply that stones have formed de novo in the bladder.
  • Most common in children younger than 10 years of age
  • Most vesical calculi are mixed
  • Ammonium acid urate, calcium oxalate, uric acid, and calcium phosphate are the most common components of primary bladder calculi

Secondary bladder stone: Forms during infection, due to bladder outflow obstruction, impaired bladder emptying, or the presence of a foreign body.

Types:

  • Calcium oxalate stones
  • Uric acid stones - occur in patients with gout but are also observed in patients with ileostomies or with bladder outlet obstruction
  • Cystine stones - in cystinuria
  • Triple phosphate stones - occur in urine infected with urea-splitting organisms

questions.text: All among the following are ionizing radiations except ______
questions.solution:
• MRI is a technique that produces topographic images by means of magnetic fields and radiofrequency waves.
  • MRI is based on the ability of a small number of protons within the body to absorb and emit radio wave energy when the body is placed within a strong magnetic field.  
  • Alpha, beta, gamma, and x-rays are ionizing radiations. Alpha and beta rays are particulate radiation (Particles) whereas gamma and x-rays are electromagnetic rays (No mass).

Physicists Peter Mansfield and Paul Lauterbur developed MRI-related techniques and they were awarded the 2003 Nobel prize in Physiology and Medicine for their discoveries.
